author: wsjcom
title: Deported Is Hardly the Word
text:
The sanitized word “deported” doesn’t adequately describe the aftermath of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising of April 1943 (“Historically Speaking: Undying Defeat From Warsaw to the Alamo,” Review, April 21). About 750 starving and sick Jews bravely fought against the heavily armed and trained massive German army, holding them back for almost a month as the world stood by and did nothing. After brutally killing thousands of Jews, the Nazis didn’t just deport the approximately 50,000 Jewish ghetto residents; they were sent to labor and concentration camps where most were murdered.
...
